Graphical abstract In this work a vanadium(III)-based catalyst was synthesized, characterized by thermogravimetric analysis, electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR), powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) and FTIR spectroscopy, and its activity was evaluated during fatty acids esterification with methanol. The solid catalyst was monitored during the catalyzed reactions, conducted under room atmosphere pressure and solvothermal conditions. The contribution of the leached fraction to the esterification conversion values was also investigated. Factorial experiments were also made, which helped investigate the interdependence between the major variables and also to adjust the experimental conditions according to the optimal results. Keywords Vanadium Heterogeneous catalysis Esterification Transesterification Biodiesel 1 Introduction The economic growth of a country is closely related to energy consumption. However, generating the energy that is necessary to stimulate a nation's economy may have a negative impact on the environment. Actions aimed at purely reducing power consumption may not be welcome because they may limit economic sectors, causing the global economy to collapse [1]. A more prudent and desirable approach is to include renewable fuels in the energy matrix, which could help reduce a nation’s dependence on external fuels and diminish the impact of greenhouse gases emission into the atmosphere [2,3]. Among several currently available energy sources, biomass appears to be the most socially friendly: small farmers could operate decentralized units to produce biofuels from plant-based sources. This biofuel production model should be advantageous over the production of fuels that require sophisticated technological advancements, which will only be available in the medium- and long-term [4]. Biodiesel and ethanol, two of the most commonly employed biofuels, can be produced from biomass. In Brazil ethanol has been used as a biofuel since the late 1970s, when the Brazilian government implemented the Pro-Alcohol program in response to the oil market crisis that had started back in 1973 [5,6]. Only in 2004–2005 was the use of biodiesel blended with mineral diesel regulated in Brazil. Since then, several efforts have been made to gradually replace conventional diesel with biodiesel [3]. The production of biodiesel as an alternative fuel relies mainly on vegetable oils transesterification and on fatty acids esterification with methanol or ethanol under homogeneous catalysis conditions. Unfortunately, biodiesel production by these means generates a large quantity of waste and consumes raw materials from non-renewable sources [6]. In this sense, heterogeneous catalysis could provide the biodiesel production process with the desirable sustainable character: heterogeneous catalysts are easy to recover and recycle, thereby minimizing the formation of residues [7–9]. In addition, considering that most methanol production is based on non-renewable sources, promoting the use of ethanol to produce a fully renewable fuel would be an interesting strategy [10]. Transition metal oxides and their derivative salts have emerged as an attractive alternative to prepare catalysts. Compounds based on these oxides and salts are stable and easy to prepare, not to mention that they display catalytic activity as a result of their Lewis and Bronsted acidity [11,12]. Recent investigations into the activity of molybdenum- and tungsten-based catalysts in lauric and oleic acids esterification with methanol and ethanol have attested to the high catalytic activity and appreciable reusability of these catalysts during the recycling steps [13,14]. Compounds containing vanadium have long been known for their various stable oxidation states. These compounds are largely useful in cancer treatment [15] and energy storage in batteries [16]; they can also act as powerful catalysts during sulfuric acid production [17], oxidative ethane dehydrogenation [18], and transesterification and esterification reactions [11,19]. Santacesaria et al. [11] evaluated the activity of vanadyl phosphate-based catalysts in vegetable oils transesterification. Although these catalysts presented low specific surface area (∼3m2/g), they afforded high conversion levels without leaching of the vanadium phase. These authors found that the activity of these catalysts depended on the vanadium oxidation state, where higher oxidation states (V5+ and V4+) were active, and a lower oxidation state (V3+) was inactive. They also found that catalyst stability was closely related to reaction time and temperature. Chandra Behera and Parida [19] studied how a solid vanadyl phosphate catalyst containing tungsten oxide (WO3-VPO) behaved during oleic acid esterification. The reaction followed the Eley–Rideal mechanism, in which oleic acid reacted with a proton that was chemisorbed onto the catalyst active site, which indicated that Bronsted acidity was an important characteristic of this type of catalyst. Solid vanadyl phosphate alone gave a conversion near 80wt.%. In the presence of up to 15wt.% of the tungsten oxide phase, conversion increased to 96wt.%, probably because the larger tungsten oxide content enhanced catalyst acidity. Although several solids containing vanadium and other metals have been proposed as heterogeneous catalysts for biodiesel production, many studies have neglected the leaching aspect. Because the soluble catalyst species should be absent from the reaction medium during heterogeneous catalysis, investigating whether any dissolved catalyst contributes to the catalytic reaction is mandatory [20]. Taufiq-Yap et al. [21] compared the activity of two catalysts, bulk CaO and a mixture of the oxides CaO and MgO·Ca2+ significantly leached from the active phase of bulk CaO and from the CaO–MgO mixture. However, these authors did not evaluate whether Ca2+ species participated in the catalytic reaction. The results showed that bulk CaO was a better transesterification catalyst than the CaO–MgO mixture, but significant Ca2+ leaching during alkyl esters production made bulk CaO reusability a major issue. Recently, Santacesaria et al. [22] examined leaching from hydrotalcites, a mixture of TiO2/SiO2 oxides, and a series of ordinary solids containing d-block metals during transesterification and esterification reactions. After treating the catalyst in methanol at 180°C for 1h, these authors filtered the catalyst off the solution and used the remaining methanol solution as reactant in a transesterification reaction. Some of the tested materials displayed high catalytic activity both as a solid and as a leached material in methanol solution, due to their solubility in the reaction medium. When the same authors assayed three solids containing lead (e.g., PbO, PbO2, and PbSO4) and their corresponding leachates as catalysts during a transesterification reaction in methanol, they found that fatty acids conversion into the corresponding alkyl esters depended on the oxide or salt solubility in methanol. For example, PbSO4 had low solubility in methanol, so fatty acids conversion into alkyl esters was low in the presence of this solid. As for PbO and PbO2, the soluble fraction had significant participation in the catalyzed reaction. The contribution of these solids should be more important during esterification reactions, because acidic medium should favor their solubilization. In this work, a vanadium(III)-based catalyst was synthesized, and its activity was evaluated during fatty acids esterification with methanol. The solid catalyst was monitored during the catalyzed reactions conducted under room atmosphere pressure and solvothermal conditions; contribution of the leached fraction to esterification was investigated. Factorial experiments helped investigate the interdependence between the major variables and adjust the experimental conditions according to the optimal results. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Lauric acid, vanadium (V) oxide, and sulfuric acid (98%) were purchased from Vetec (Brazil). Methanol, ethanol (99.5%), and NaOH (99%) were acquired from Biotec (Brazil). Solid sulfur and carbon disulfide were supplied by Cinética Química Ltda (Brazil). 2.2 Catalyst preparation Vanadium(III) sulfate, V2(SO4)3, was synthesized according to the literature [23]. To this end, vanadium(V) oxide (18mmol), sulfur (23mmol), and sulfuric acid (24mL) were added to a three-neck flask and submitted to reflux under magnetic stirring at 473K, for 30h. Then, the reaction was filtered through a fritted filter and the remaining solid was washed with water. Next, the solid was suspended in 10mL of an ethanol/water solution (50% v/v), 10mL of carbon disulfide was added to the suspension, and the system was stirred for 30min. The pale yellow solid remaining after filtration of the suspension through a fritted filter was stored under vacuum. The yield of the synthesis was 75.40%. V2(SO4)3 solubility was tested in different solvents (methanol, ethanol, chloroform, acetone, acetonitrile, toluene, ethyl ether, chloromethane, concentrated sulfuric acid, distilled water, distilled heated water, hydrazine hydrate, and concentrated and dilute nitric acid). This solid was insoluble in most of the analyzed solvents at the tested temperature. The strength and distribution of the acid sites on the V2(SO4)3 surface were investigated by using n-butylamine as base. For this purpose, a sample of V2(SO4)3 was placed under argon flow for 1h [13]. Then, the sample was placed in contact with a stream of n-butylamine vapor (previously bled for 1h) in a degassed glass vessel kept at 100°C, for 2h. After this period, the sample was cooled to room temperature under inert atmosphere (argon); cooling took about 30min V2(SO4)3 samples containing n-butylamine were characterized by TGA. TGA analysis was conducted on a Thermal Analyst 2100 from TA Instruments SDT Q600 with simultaneous DTA–TG [13]. 2.3 Characterization techniques The synthesized V2(SO4)3 was characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), and electronic paramagnetic resonance (EPR). For the PXRD analysis, self-oriented films were placed on neutral glass sample holders. The patterns were obtained on a Shimadzu XRD-6000 diffractometer, in the reflection mode. The equipment was operated at 40kV and 40mA; CuKα radiation (λ =1.5418Å) and a dwell time of 1°min−1 were employed. The FTIR spectra were recorded on a Biorad 3500 GX spectrophotometer in the 400–4000cm−1 range. The KBr pellets were obtained by crushing the solids (1mg) with spectroscopic grade KBr (100mg). All the spectra were collected with a resolution of 4cm−1 and an accumulation of 32 scans. Thermogravimetric measurements (TGA) were performed on a Thermal Analyst TA Instrument SDT 600 Simultaneous DTA–TGA–DSC, in nitrogen, with a heating rate of 20°Cmin−1, from 25 to 1200°C. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) measurements of the compounds were accomplished on an EPR BRUKER EMX microX spectrometer (frequency X, band 9.5GHz), at room temperature and 77K (using liquid N2), using perpendicular microwave polarization X-band. 2.4 Catalytic activity Lauric or oleic acid esterification reactions were performed under room atmospheric pressure and alcohol reflux. The fatty acid (about 1.0g), an appropriate amount of methanol, and the solid catalyst, V2(SO4)3, were added to the reaction flask (125-mL two-neck flask). The reaction mixture was vigorously stirred under the vapor pressure of the alcohol reflux for the required reaction time, at 60°C; heating was conducted by using a silicone bath. In this step different reaction conditions were analyzed, such as the amount of methanol (1:3 and 1:12 acid: alcohol molar ratio), temperature (90 and 120°C), percentage of catalysis (1% and 10% mass/mass percentage) and time (1 and 3h), all the conditions can be found in Tables 5 and 6 . After cooling to room temperature, the reaction mixture was centrifuged, and V2(SO4)3 was recovered for reactivation and reuse. For recycling purposes, V2(SO4)3 was thoroughly washed with ethanol and dried at 120°C. The V2(SO4)3 reuse capacity was evaluated in sequential reactions similar to the reaction described above. The excess alcohol present in the supernatant solution was removed by evaporation under low pressure, and fatty acid conversion to the corresponding alkyl ester was assayed by titration of the remaining acidity with a standard NaOH 0.01molL−1 solution. Esterification reactions were also performed under vapor pressure of the alcohol and solvothermal conditions, inside a 15-mL closed Teflon vessel fitted into a closed stainless reactor. The reactor was placed in a silicone bath, to ensure constant temperature, and submitted to magnetic stirring at 1150rpm. The fatty acid (1.0g), an appropriate amount of the alcohol, and V2(SO4)3 were added to the reaction vessel, and the reaction mixture was vigorously stirred under the vapor pressure of the alcohol for the required reaction time. After cooling to room temperature, the reaction mixture was centrifuged and V2(SO4)3 was recovered for reuse capacity investigation in sequential reactions similar to the reaction described above. Reaction conversion was calculated. 2.5 Leaching and solid degradation studies To evaluate the solubility of the catalyst V2(SO4)3 in the reaction conditions and the catalytic activity of the solubilized V2(SO4)3 fraction, a series of experiments were carried out. Table 1 summarizes the experimental steps as well as the labeling of the solids and the supernatants obtained along the process. Experiment a: The steel reactor was placed in the same Teflon reaction flask used for the lauric acid esterification reaction under solvothermal conditions. V2(SO4)3 (designated solid 1, 1.00g) and methanol (6.1mL) were added to the reaction flask and submitted to magnetic stirring at 120°C (silicone bath) for 1h, under solvothermal conditions. The amounts of V2(SO4)3 and methanol as well as the conditions used in the experiment were the same as those reported above for the esterification reactions under solvothermal conditions (10% catalyst/acid m/m ratio and lauric acid/alcohol molar ratio of 1:3). After 1h, the reactor was cooled to room temperature, and the suspension was centrifuged at 4000rpm for 20min, to give solid 2 and supernatant 1. Experiment b: The solid originated from Experiment a (solid 2) was washed with methanol, dried at 100°C for 24h, and kept under vacuum. Solvent (methanol) was added to the supernatant originated from Experiment a (supernatant 1). Both solid 2 washed with methanol and supernatant 1 after adding methanol were analyzed by EPR; solid 2 washed with methanol was also analyzed by FTIR. Experiement c: Supernatant 1 was dried to remove methanol and the resulting solid, labeled solid 3, was analyzed by EPR. Experiment d: Solid 3 was used as catalyst for lauric acid esterification, accomplished in the following conditions lauric acid/alcohol molar ratio of 1:3, 10% catalyst/acid m/m ratio, 120°C, 1h, magnetic stirring, and solvothermal conditions. After the reaction, the reactor was cooled to room temperature. All the catalyst species was solubilized in the reaction mixture, so excess methanol in the reaction solution was removed by evaporation. Phase separation (a colorless phase and a blue-greenish phase) occurred. Both phases were analyzed by EPR. The reaction product was titrated with NaOH 0.01mol/L. Experiment e: Solid 2 (resulting from Experiment a) was suspended in a new portion of methanol, and the processes described in Experiments b–d were repeated (renamed as Experiments b́–d́). Experiment b́ provided solid 4 and supernatant 2; Experiment ć gave solid 5. Experiment f: Solid 4 was suspended in a new portion of methanol, and the processes described in Experiments b–d were repeated again (renamed as Experiments b́́–d́́). Experiment b́́ provided solid 6 and supernatant 3; Experiment ć́ gave solid 7. Experiment g (also designated extra cycle): Solid 6, recovered from Experiment f, was used as catalyst during lauric acid esterification under the following conditions: lauric acid/alcohol molar ratio of 1:3, 10% catalyst/acid m/m ratio, 120°C, 1h, magnetic stirring, and solvothermal conditions. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Solid catalyst preparation and characterization The solid catalyst V2(SO4)3 was synthesized by reacting vanadium(V) oxide, V2O5, with solid sulfur; the yield was 75.40% [23]. The resulting V2(SO4)3 was a pale lemon-yellow solid that was quite stable in air atmosphere [23]. However, this solid decomposed into two different solids depending on the storage conditions. Heating under vacuum or high pressure oxidized vanadium(III) to vanadium(IV) oxo-sulfate (VOSO4, a blue solid) and SO2, whereas exposure to air for a few days afforded a green hydrate species (V2(SO4)3·7H2O). V2(SO4)3 was insoluble in most of the tested solvents [23] in ordinary conditions (Table S1, Supplementary material). X-ray diffraction analysis of V2(SO4)3 (Fig. 1 a) revealed the diffraction pattern expected for such compound (JCPDS card number 42 0231). XRD reflections emerged at 2θ =14.82, 20.34, 24.78, 29.82, and 32.58, which corresponded to the diffraction planes 012, 104, 113, 024, and 116, respectively, typical of the V2(SO4)3 face-centered rhombohedral conformation. FTIR analysis of V2(SO4)3 (Fig. S1) showed the characteristic bands [24–26] of the prepared compound. The band near 3435cm−1, assigned to water OH vibration, was attributed to V2(SO4)3 hydration water or water adsorbed onto V2(SO4)3 after the synthesis. The four typical vibrational modes of sulfate appeared at 1000–850cm−1 (v 1), 500–400cm−1 (ν 2), 1255–880cm−1 (ν 3), and 720–600cm−1 (ν 4). Because the free SO4 group has Td symmetry, only the vibrational modes ν 3 and v 4 emerged in the FTIR spectrum. V2(SO4)3 may have C3v symmetry (with the sulfate group monocoordinated to the metal ion) or C2v symmetry (with the sulfate group bis-coordinated to the metal ion or serving as a bridge between two metal centers). As a result of these decreased symmetries, the FTIR spectrum of V2(SO4)3 exhibited more intense bands for all the vibrational modes. In addition, under the C2v symmetry, the bands corresponding to ν 3 and ν 4 could split into three other bands [27]. The FTIR spectrum of V2(SO4)3 (Fig. S1, Supplementary material) displayed bands at 1277cm−1, 1240cm−1, and 1127cm−1, indicating that the band due to ν 3 possibly split into three other bands, suggesting that the sulfate group is bis-coordinated to the vanadium(III) ion [27]. The region between 850 and 1200cm−1 in the FTIR spectrum of V2(SO4)3 presented strong bands, which were assigned to SO stretching. The region between 720 and 500cm−1 exhibited bands due to the SO4 2− bending modes (Fig. S1, Supplementary material). 3.2 Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) V2(SO4)3 stored under vacuum was analyzed by TGA (Fig. S2, Supplementary material). The thermogram revealed a mass loss pattern typical of hydrated solids containing sulfate ions [28,29]. The TG curves and its derivate (Fig. S2) displays four mass loss steps, from room temperature until 400°C (7.73%) assigned to the loss of water molecules. The mass loss between 400–650°C (46%) can probably be related to SO3 and/or SO2 loss [28,29]. All the processes are slightly endothermal. The total mass loss from room temperature to 1000°C is about 54% of the initial weight of the sample. It is also possible to observe (Fig. S2) around the 678°C (a region apparently without loss mass), in both DTA and DSC, the presence of the endothermic peak that may indicate phase shift (oxide or crystallization of vanadium oxide) which can be produced as exemplified by the reaction: V2(SO4)3 →V2O5 +3 SO2 +½ O2. In this case the oxide could be absorbing energy for structural changes [28]. TGA analysis of V2(SO4)3 after exposed to air atmosphere (Fig. S3) demonstrated that mass loss due to SO2 and SO3 removal undergoes a small reduction compared to the TGA in nitrogen atmosphere (Fig. S2, from 46% to about 35%). This can be attributed to an oxidant atmosphere present in that experiment, which promotes the oxidation of vanadium ions. Apart from that, a more pronounced water loss can be also observed (from 7.33% to about 33%). This probably happened because exposure of the anhydrous salt V2(SO4)3 to hydrated air can form the V2(SO4)3·7H2O species (Fig. S3, Supplementary material). The total mass loss from room temperature to 1000°C is about 68% of the initial weight of the sample used and it can be explained (because) on basis of the hydrated material that was formed in this experimental conditions. V2(SO4)3 was also analyzed by TGA after being used as a catalyst during esterification reaction under solvothermal conditions. Fig. S4 also shows a large peak between 400 and 600°C, only less pronounced than the peaks observed in Figs. S2 and S3, suggesting that V2(SO4)3 also lost a mixture of SO x molecules. Comparison of the catalyst TGA profiles (in the region of 200°C), recorded before (Fig. S2, Supplementary material) and after (Fig. S4, Supplementary material) the esterification reaction suggested that V2(SO4)3 became hydrated along of the catalytic process. It can be noticed, in the region between room temperature and 400°C, the presence of new weight loss peaks at about 57, 84 and 264°C, which can probably be attributed to the elimination of employed reactants used in the esterification reaction. The mass loss in the region of room temperature and 400°C was about 37%, whereas in region between 400 and 650°C was 28%. That can be an indication that the solvent elimination could be restraining SO x elimination or yet that it is being formed and being diluted in reaction. 3.3 Electronic paramagnetic resonance (EPR) Fig. 2 depicts the EPR spectrum of the freshly synthesized V2(SO4)3 measured at the X-band frequency, at T =77K. The EPR spectrum showed a single isotropic signal with g-factor of 1.9575 (determined by using the Bruker WinEPR Simfonia simulation pack®), typical of a d 2 ion system [30,31]. Ions with integer spin, such as vanadium(III) (S =1), are often silent to conventional EPR spectroscopy. This results from the large zero-field splitting of the ground state, which is inherent to non-Kramers ions [30–32]. On the other hand, when the symmetry around the metal ion is high, the zero-field splitting is small, and it is possible to conduct conventional EPR analysis instead of HFEPR analysis [33]. 3.4 Acid sites investigation TGA analysis helped to investigate V2(SO4)3 treated with n-butylamine vapor. This technique allowed us to observe all the possible types of base desorption at different temperatures, including desorption of n-butylamine molecules (a) physically adsorbed onto V2(SO4)3 via weak forces (under 110°C), (b) chemisorbed onto weak acid sites (110–230°C), (c) chemisorbed onto medium-strength acid sites (230–480°C), and (d) chemisorbed onto strong acid sites (480–650°C) [13]. Fig. 3 displays the TGA results obtained after base adsorption. The total mass loss comprised four stages (representing the four largest mass losses). Table 2 presents mass loss in weight percentage. Comparison of these TGA results (Fig. 3) with the TGA results obtained for the freshly prepared V2(SO4)3 showed that water, SO2, and SO3 loss occurred in the same region as n-butylamine desorption [28,29]. The TGA results achieved for the freshly prepared V2(SO4)3 were separated into six different regions, to better compare to the TGA obtained after the absortion of n-butylamine: (i) region 1′ was defined between 38 and 95°C, with 1.35% (0.2025mg) of mass loss; (ii) region 2′ was between 120 and 160°C, with 1.10% (0.1650mg); (iii) between 190 and 220°C was defined region 3′, which showed 0.44% (0.06600mg) of mass loss; (iv) region 4′ was defined between 350 and 390°C, which showed 0.75% (0.1125mg) of mass loss; (v) between 470 and 590°C was defined region 5′, with 26.08% (3.912mg) of mass loss; (vi) region 590 and 665°C was defined region 6′, which showed 23.81% (3.571mg) of mass loss (Fig. S5 and Table S2, Supplementary material). A large mass loss took place between 37 and 185°C (Table 2, region 1, 0.4035mg) for V2(SO4)3 containing adsorbed n-butylamine. This mass loss was greater than the mass loss verified during TGA analysis of the freshly prepared V2(SO4)3 (regions 1′ and 2′, 0.3675mg). Therefore, of the 0.4035mg of mass loss detected for V2(SO4)3 containing adsorbed n-butylamine, 0.3675mg corresponded to loss of hydration water [34], whereas 0.0361mg (4.94×10−7 mol) referred to loss of physiosorbed n-butylamine [13]. In the same way, the region between 320 and 390°C had a greater mass loss for V2(SO4)3 containing adsorbed n-butylamine (Table 2, region 2, 0.9811mg) when compared with the freshly prepared V2(SO4)3 (region 4′, 0.1125mg). Hence, 0.1125mg of the 0.9811mg lost by V2(SO4)3 containing adsorbed n-butylamine could be related to adsorbed water, whilst 0.8686mg (1.187×10−5 mol) could be associated with n-butylamine bound to weak acid sites [13]. The region between 423 and 468°C (Table 2, region 3, 0.3075mg) only appeared in the TGA profile of V2(SO4)3 containing adsorbed n-butylamine. Thus, all the 0.3075mg lost at this stage can be ascribed to n-butylamine (4.204×10−6 mol) adsorbed onto medium-strength acid sites. Table 3 relates the quantity (inmmolg−1 of solid) of acid sites to the types of acid sites in V2(SO4)3. 3.5 Catalytic activity V2(SO4)3 was used as catalyst in oleic and lauric acid esterification reactions by methanol under different conditions. Table 4 brings the conversion results. 3.6 Oleic acid esterification As a catalyst during oleic acid esterification under room atmospheric pressure and methanol reflux at 90°C (stabilized with a large condenser), V2(SO4)3 gave conversion of about 86% (Table 4, run 1). The use of V2(SO4)3 under solvothermal conditions (reaction taking place inside a steel reactor, in a silicone bath) afforded similar results (Table 4, run 2, with a conversion of about 87%). Therefore, the best possible results provided by V2(SO4)3 during oleic acid esterification were yields around 86%, and ordinary conditions (methanol reflux) sufficed to ensure the catalytic potential of V2(SO4)3. The data were comparable to the results reported by other researchers who worked with more drastic experimental conditions. For example, do Nascimento et al. obtained methyl oleate conversion of 84.2% in an esterification reaction conducted at 130°C, for 2h, under solvothermal conditions and at an acid/alcohol molar ratio of 1:60 [35]. 3.7 Lauric acid As catalyst, V2(SO4)3 afforded moderate conversion yield 74% during lauric acid esterification under room atmospheric pressure and methanol reflux (Table 4, run 3). The catalyst species did not leach into the solution, as attested by the colorless supernatant obtained after the reaction. The moderate conversion, the mild reaction conditions (alcohol reflux temperature) and the high catalyst recovery percentage after simple filtration pointed to the high potential of V2(SO4)3 as catalyst for esterification reactions. Zatta et al. achieved about 75% lauric acid conversion into the corresponding ester by using more drastic conditions than the ones employed here; i.e., their reaction was carried out in a Cyclone Büchi glasuster miniclave drive reactor for 2h, at a stirring speed of 500rpm and acid/alcohol molar ratio of 1:12, without a solid catalyst [36]. The catalytic activity of V2(SO4)3 during lauric acid esterification with methanol was also investigated under solvothermal conditions (Table 5). A statistical study accomplished according to the full 24 factorial design helped to assess how each experimental variable and the interactions between these variables influenced the process [37] (Table 5). Different combinations of experimental conditions gave the best conversion values (higher than 95%, Table 4, runs 6–8, 10, and 14–16). Full 24 factorial design revealed several one- and two-way interaction effects, mainly to catalyst concentration (+19.14), reaction time (+18.59) and interaction of these factors (−9.51) (Fig. S6, Supplementary material). However, the statistical significance of the 2*3*4 three-way interaction effects (+8.04) implied the need for simultaneous analysis, which was better illustrated by the representation in Fig. 4 (temperature, catalyst concentration, and acid/alcohol molar ratio). Each plot shows the means (points) connected by lines when the conditions −1.0 (minimum level) were changed to +1.0 (maximum level) for all the analyzed factors (Table 5). This three-way interaction (2*3*4) evidenced that the two-way interaction plot (2*4) changed its behavior upon modification of catalyst concentration (3). Interestingly, the two most significant three-way interactions involved the variable temperature (2*3*4 and 1*2*3), although the main effect was the smallest of all the calculated effects. This happened because the average conversion percentage increased (by about 8.7%) with rising temperature for 10% catalyst concentration for both acid/alcohol molar ratios. Nevertheless, in the presence of 1% catalyst concentration, the average conversion percentage decreased (about 8.8%). Despite annulment, it was clear that the temperature effect existed. Considering the factorial design results, the standard deviation of the conversion percentage determined by acid titration, the reagents cost, and the tested system, the best experimental conditions were: acid/alcohol molar ratio of 1:3, 120°C, and 10% catalyst/acid m/m ratio. 3.8 Determination of the activation energy of the catalyzed lauric acid esterification with methanol Table 6 shows that catalyzed lauric acid esterification with methanol strongly depended on reaction temperature. The reaction rate constant can be related to the temperature at which the reaction proceeds. Based on the relation between reaction time and the reaction rate constant (−ln [1–n]= kT, where n is the value of catalyzed lauric acid conversion into methyl laurate), the parameters k and ln k can be calculated. The activation energy (E a) can be obtained by using the Arrhenius equation (k =Ae−E a/RT ) [9,13], which includes the activation energy ‘E a’ and the frequency factor ‘A’. R is the universal molar gas constant, and T is the temperature in K. Because E a depends on temperature, the rate constant at any temperature (within the validity of the Arrhenius equation) can be determined by using the equation ln k =ln A− E a/RT, which is a linear equation, and a plot of ln k versus 1/T gives a straight line with slope equal to E a/R (Table 7 and Fig. 5 ). The plot of ln k versus 1/T depicted in Fig. 6 validated the first order of the reaction [13]. The E a of the reaction was 23.75kJmol−1, which was similar to the E a determined for: catalyzed myristic acid esterification under more drastic reaction conditions (22.51kJmol−1) [38], catalyzed oleic acid esterification using 0.1g of catalyst, acid/alcohol molar ratio of 1:40, 4h, and temperature of 60°C (50kJmol−1) [39] and catalyzed lauric acid esterification with butanol (78kJmol−1) [40]. To compare the catalyzed and the non-catalyzed reaction under the same experimental conditions (solvothermal conditions), the E a of the non-catalyzed reaction was determined in the same way as the E a of the catalyzed system was obtained. Tables 8 and 9 list the conversion yields and the calculation of ln k and T −1, respectively. The slope of the line ln k vs T −1 was equal to E a/R, which enabled E a determination (Fig. 6). As expected, the non-catalyzed reaction had higher E a, about 35.52kJmol−1, as compared with the catalyzed esterification, which attested to the efficiency of the catalyst V2(SO4)3 in the reaction conditions. 3.9 Kinetic evaluation of lauric acid esterification with methanol under room atmospheric pressure—methanol reflux The reaction under closed system was fast: the maximum rate was reached within only one hour. In this case, it is not appropriate to analyze the turnover frequency (TOF). This would require shorter reaction times, which is impossible to achieve in a closed system where the reactor takes about 15min to warm, and reactions taking less than 15min would give unreliable and non-reproducible yields. To enable reactions that take shorter times and ensure reliable yields, kinetics was evaluated in an open system (already described in part 2.4). In such system, the glass flask should warm faster than the stainless reactor capsule. A further advantage of the open system would be the possibility of determining rates along the reaction course instead of conducting many reactions to organize the kinetic curve. According to the literature, lauric acid esterification with methanol is a pseudo first-order reaction where methanol concentration is high, so it can be considered almost invariable throughout the reaction [13]. TOF can be calculated from the angular coefficient of the plot of n ester vs time, before the maximum conversion point is reached [41]. Fig. 7 brings this plot, where the dotted line represents the points used to determine TOF. The reaction reached maximum conversion within approximately 120min; a plateau emerged thereafter. Only the points before the plateau were used to calculate TOF for this reaction. TOF was 61.97h−1, which was higher than the TOF value described for this same reaction under similar conditions (60°C, acid/methanol molar ratio=1:30, di-hexylether as internal standard, and mesoporous sulfonic acid as catalyst) in the literature [42]. 3.10 Catalyst solubility and recycling tests When using a solid as catalyst in heterogeneous catalytic processes, it is important to guarantee that no soluble catalytic species exist in the reaction medium. In fact, the real problem is to quantify the contribution of the homogeneous and the heterogeneous processes to total conversion. Ensuring the absence of soluble catalytic species in the reaction medium also facilitates the purification of reaction products. Among the main advantages of heterogeneous catalysis is reusability of the solid catalyst. However, solid catalyst leaching to the reaction solution or its decomposition to a new non-catalytic species hinders catalyst recycling. The possibility and extent of catalyst solubilization or deactivation must be controlled during investigations into heterogeneous catalyst reuse. To investigate the stability of solid V2(SO4)3 with respect to leaching and decomposition under solvothermal reaction conditions, freshly prepared V2(SO4)3 (designated solid 1, Table 1) was placed in pure methanol at 120°C for 1h under solvothermal conditions, but without fatty acid, to mimic a catalytic reaction. The resulting methanol solution, labeled supernatant 1, and the resulting solid, designated solid 2, were then analyzed by EPR (Figs. 8 and 9 ). It was not necessary to conduct the same experiment under room atmospheric pressure and methanol reflux because the color of the solution does not indicate the presence of vanadium species in solution, which demonstrates that the catalyst did not leach or decompose in these conditions. After drying at 60°C, solid 2 was analyzed by EPR (Fig. 8); supernatant 1 (Experiment b, Table 1) was evaluated by EPR, too. The EPR spectrum of solid 2 (Fig. 8a) and the corresponding simulated EPR spectrum (Fig. 8b) resembled the EPR spectrum of solid 1 (Fig. 2) [43–47]. The similar EPR spectra suggested that the species in solids 1 and 2 were the same, and that the vanadium(III) species did not undergo any significant oxi-reduction. Only V2(SO4)3 solubilization occurred [30]. Fig. 9a and b contain the EPR spectrum of supernatant 1 and the corresponding simulated spectrum, respectively. The spectrum displayed parallel and perpendicular EPR signals with 16 lines. The EPR parameters were g⊥=1.935 and g // =1.978, and A⊥=181.0×10−4 cm−1 and A // =69.0×10−4 cm−1, as calculated by spectrum simulation using the Bruker WinEPR Simfonia simulation pack® (Fig. 9b). These parameters were typical of the spectrum of magnetically isolated vanadium(IV) ions [46]. This analysis indicated that, under solvothermal conditions, part of vanadium(III) present in solid 1 oxidized to vanadium(IV), which solubilized in the reaction solvent (supernatant 1). However, supernatant 1 was green, so the presence of vanadium(III) species in this supernatant was not dismissed. Drying of supernatant 1 and total methanol evaporation furnished a dark green solid, designated solid 3. The EPR spectrum of solid 3 (not shown) resembled the EPR spectrum of supernatant 1: the EPR parameters g and A were the same, which suggested that the species present in solid 3 corresponded to vanadium(IV) species. By weighing the mass of solid 2 and solid 3, it was possible to estimate the total amount of vanadium species that leached from solid 1 (experiments were conducted at least in duplicate). The total percentage of solid 3; i.e., the total percentage of solid that leached from solid 1 into supernatant 1, was 32.06%±2.38%. The mass weighed for solid 2 was 80.10%±2.67%. The sum of the masses of solids 2 and 3 was higher than 100%. Hence, solid 3 still contained some methanol, another compound or humidity. To investigate the stability of solid V2(SO4)3 with respect to leaching and decomposition under solvothermal reaction conditions in recycling experiments, solid 2 was placed in pure methanol at 120°C for 1h under solvothermal conditions, but without fatty acid, to mimic a catalytic reuse reaction. This process afforded solid 4 and supernatant 2. Supernatant 2 was dried, to give solid 5 (Experiment e, Table 1). EPR analyses of solid 4 and supernatant 2 provided the same results obtained for solid 2 and supernatant 1, respectively, suggesting that the same type of leaching process occurred during catalyst reuse. In addition, the EPR spectrum of solid 5, obtained after drying of supernatant 2, resembled the EPR spectrum of solid 3. Solid 4 was used in a third solubility test (Experiment f, Table 1), to give solid 6 and supernatant 3, whose EPR spectra resembled the EPR spectra of solid 1 and supernatant 1, respectively. In the same way, solid 7, obtained after drying of supernatant 3, had EPR spectrum similar to the EPR spectrum of solid 3. To analyze whether the solid V2(SO4)3 still displayed catalytic activity after three leaching cycles, solid 6 was used as catalyst in a lauric acid esterification reaction with methanol. This experimental part was designated extra cycle (Table 1, Experiment g), and the catalytic result is presented in Table 11, run 4. Solids 3, 5, and 7 were also used as catalysts for lauric acid esterification with methanol (Table 10 ; runs 1, 2, and 3, respectively), and the results of the conversion and percentage of recovered solid can be seen in Table 10. Based on the results depicted in Table 10, the soluble part that leached from the solid catalyst (solid 1) accounted for 80.62% of conversion. Because the EPR spectra of supernatants 1, 2, and 3, which contained leached catalyst, were typical of vanadium(IV) species and since the leached catalyst also contributed to the conversion results, a lauric acid esterification reaction with methanol was accomplished by using VOSO4 as catalyst, in the following conditions: lauric acid/alcohol molar ratio of 1:3, 10% catalyst/acid m/m ratio, 120°C, 1h, magnetic stirring, and solvothermal conditions (Table 10, run 5). Solid VOSO4 is blue, but it solubilized and became green under the reaction conditions, resembling the color of leached part of V2(SO4)3. The reactions catalyzed by solids 3, 5, and 7 (obtained from catalyst leaching to the supernatant, see Table 1) gave conversions of between 80 and 90%. These data were similar to the result obtained by using VOSO4 as catalyst (87.00%±3.36%). These findings suggested that the vanadium(III) present in the solid V2(SO4)3 probably leached into the solution as vanadium(IV) and catalyzed the esterification reaction. The latter species accounted for most of the conversion results observed in Table 4 for lauric acid esterification with methanol under solvothermal conditions. In contrast, under room atmospheric pressure and methanol reflux, V2(SO4)3 did not solubilize. Finally, although the VOSO4 shows a 87.00% conversions, reactions 1–3 using V2(SO4)3 (Table 10) did not reached this conversion value, probably because during the catalytic reaction using the solid V2(SO4)3 not all the vanadium(III) species degrades into vanadium(IV) species in solution. Run 4 gave higher conversion than runs 1–3, which suggests that most of the acid was converted to ester via action of soluble vanadium(IV) species, although vanadium(III) also participated in the catalysis, accounting for approximately 8% of the conversion. 4 Conclusions Preparation and characterization of solid V2(SO4)3 helped to investigate the catalytic activity of this salt in fatty acids esterification with methanol at room atmospheric pressure and under solvothermal experimental conditions. Solid V2(SO4)3 is insoluble in the reaction solvent (methanol) and affords high fatty acids conversion at room atmospheric pressure. In this condition, the catalytic process is totally heterogeneous, and there is no evidence of catalyst solubilization in the reaction medium. Under more drastic reaction conditions; e.g., solvothermal conditions, solid V2(SO4)3 is partially soluble and part of it oxidizes to a new species. EPR analysis suggests that this species is vanadium(IV). Evaluation of the catalytic reaction as to its real heterogeneous or homogeneous character showed that, under drastic reaction conditions (solvothermal conditions), over 80% of lauric acid conversion into methyl laurate is also due to homogeneous catalysis by vanadium(IV) species. However, catalysis using V2(SO4)3 solid in a reaction process that does not involve partial catalyst solubilization gives 97.3% conversion, which indicates that the reaction can also be catalyzed by heterogeneous vanadium(III) species. FTIR analysis pointed out the chelate bidentate behavior of the sulfate ligands in solid V2(SO4)3. Three different types of acid sites exist in this solid: physiosorption sites (0.03291mmolg−1), weak chemisorption sites (0.7913mmolg−1), and medium-strength chemisorption sites (0.2803mmolg−1), justifying the high catalytic activity of solid V2(SO4)3. The activation energy of the non-catalyzed reaction (34.27kJmol−1) is higher than the activation energy of the catalyzed reaction (23.75kJmol−1), as expected. The TOF of the catalyzed esterification reaction is 61.97h−1, which is higher than the TOF described in the literature for the same reaction catalyzed by another solid. Finally, analysis of lauric acid esterification with methanol under solvothermal conditions by the 24 factorial design showed that temperature vs catalyst concentration vs alcohol/acid molar ratio interactions were the most significant for the results. coredata.dc:description: In this work a vanadium(III)-based catalyst was synthesized, characterized by thermogravimetric analysis, electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR), powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) and FTIR spectroscopy, and its activity was evaluated during fatty acids esterification with methanol. The solid catalyst was monitored during the catalyzed reactions, conducted under room atmosphere pressure and solvothermal conditions. The contribution of the leached fraction to the esterification conversion values was also investigated. Factorial experiments were also made, which helped investigate the interdependence between the major variables and also to adjust the experimental conditions according to the optimal results.
coredata.dc:title: Heterogeneous/homogeneous esterification reaction catalyzed by a solid based on a vanadium salt
coredata.prism:issueName: Contributions of Homogeneous and Heterogeneous Catalysis in Biorefining: Special Issue in Honor of Prof. Ulf Schuchardt
